questions.text: What percentage of children's total daily energy requirement can come from Vanaspati ghee?
questions.solution:
Vanaspati ghee and other hydrogenated oils are trans fat. Trans fat is not recommended in children according to current dietary guidelines.

 Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents:

  • Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy
  • Saturated fat is less than 10% of total daily energy
  • Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day
  • No trans-fat

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the graphical representation of data given below?

choices.text: Represents the trend of events with the passage of time
Can be simple, multiple or component types
Depicts the relationship between two variables

questions.solution:
A scatter plot is a statistical map used to study the correlation between two given variables.

In scatter plots or scatter diagrams, the pattern made by plotted points along the two axes indicates the possible relationship. If the dots cluster along a straight line, then the relationship is of a linear nature. If there is no cluster, then there might be no relationship. Below is an example of a scatter diagram without a linear relation.

Option A: A line diagram or line graph represents the trend of events with the passage of time.

Option B: A histogram is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains class intervals along one axis and the frequencies along the other axis showing the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.

Option C: A bar graph is a pictorial way of presenting a set of numbers, the magnitudes of which are proportional to the length of the bars in the graph. It can be simple, multiple, or component bar graphs and enable values to be compared visually. They are used to compare a single variable value between several groups.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man wants to join a factory for work and he enquires about the working hours. According to the Indian Factories Act, of 1948, which among the following is not true regarding the working hours of an adult?

choices.text: Spread-over period of work in a factory is 12 hours
Maximum of 72 working hours per week
Rest for at least ½ hour after 5 hours of continuous work

questions.solution:
The Factories Act, of 1948, has prescribed a maximum of 48 working hours per week. The total number of hours of work in a week, including overtime, shall not exceed 60 hours. 

The number of work hours should not exceed 9 hours per day with a rest of at least ½ hour after 5 hours of continuous work (Options A and D). For adolescents, the hours of work have been reduced from 5 hours to 4 ½ hours per day.

The 1976 amendment makes a provision to increase the spread-over period of work of an employee in a factory up to 12 hours from the existing 10 ½ hours (Option B). Spread over period means the time of entry to the time of exit for an employee in the factory.

Labour Day is celebrated every year across the world on the 1st of May to spread awareness about the rights and opportunities every labor should get for their welfare and betterment.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A neonatology study was conducted between 2 groups of newborns by measuring their weights. Assigning the neonates to 2 groups was based on whether their mothers did or did not receive food supplements during the antenatal period. Which of the following statistical tests can be used to correlate the means obtained?
questions.solution:
The above study tests the difference between the sample means of 2 independent groups (weights of newborns of mothers who did or did not receive food supplements in the antenatal period). Student’s t-test (unpaired t-test) can be used to compare the means of 2 groups that are independent of each other.

Means can only be calculated for quantitative variables; hence, we use the parametric tests here. The type of parametric test to be used depends on the number of groups being tested.

Other options:

Option A- Paired t-test is used for a single sample to test the difference between two paired results. 

Option C- ANOVA method is used to assess the relative size of variance among the group means compared to the average variance within the groups. ANOVA is used to compare means among three or more groups.

Option D- Chi-square test is a non-parametric test used to analyze the differences when two dependable variables are measured at a nominal level.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following values of a test applied to this population will be required to calculate the negative predictive value?
questions.solution:
A and B values are required to calculate the negative predictive value. A negative predictive value is given by the formula:

Negative Predictive Value = True Negative/Total negatives,

where Total negatives = True negative + False negative. 

From the diagram, 

A- True negative

B- False negative

C- False positive

D- True positive

So, NPV= A/ A+B

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: You would advise on-site chemical pre-treatment before incineration for all of the following biomedical waste except ____
questions.solution:
Urine bags do not have to undergo on-site chemical pre-treatment to sterilize before handing them over for incineration.

As per NACO or WHO guidelines, laboratory waste, microbiological waste, blood samples, blood bags should be sterilized with non-chlorinated chemicals on-site. After this, it should be handed over to the common bio-medical waste treatment and disposal facility for incineration.

questions.text:
Two doctors examined 50 CT scans of patients. The kappa statistic was found to be 0.45. What does it mean?

CT - Computed tomography
questions.solution:
A kappa statistic of 0.45 indicates a moderate agreement between the two doctors who collected the data.

The strength of agreement varies with the kappa coefficient as follows:

0.81 to 1: perfect agreement between the two tests/methods
0.61 to 0.80: substantial agreement/ good agreement
0.41 to 0.60: moderate agreement
0.21 to 0.40: fair agreement
0.10 to 0.20: slight agreement

Most of the studies test the association between an exposure variable and the disease. In certain cases, it is anticipated that there will be a correlation between the variables, and the challenge is to determine the extent of this correlation or association. This assertion holds special significance in the realm of reliability studies, wherein the researcher seeks to quantitatively assess the extent to which a given variable (such as a particular finding on a CT scan) can be reproduced through several measurements which is the utility of the kappa statistic. It is also important to note that a chi-square test can also be used but would only qualitatively assess the data and not quantitatively which of course is accomplished by the use of kappa statistic.

Kappa statistic can be calculated as:

where pO is observed agreement and pE is expected agreement.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for a newborn stabilization unit?

choices.text: It is located in the delivery room
It is for sick babies and LBW babies < 1800 g
It is present in all community health centres
All cases except major surgeries are managed here

questions.solution:
A newborn stabilization unit is present in all community health centers (CHC).

Facility-based newborn care services include:

  Newborn care corner Newborn stabilization unit Special newborn care units
Present in Delivery rooms of all centers and hospitals Within or close to the maternity ward, in CHCs, and first referral units District hospitals and facilities with >3000 deliveries/ year
Admits Immediate care to all newborns Sick and LBW >1800 gms Sick and LBW< 1800 gms
Service Immediate resuscitation, early initiation of breastfeeding, identification, and referral of at-risk newborns Hyperbilirubinemia, asphyxia, pneumonia, diarrhea, sepsis All care except assisted ventilation and major surgery
Training of health personnel appointed 2 days, under Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram 11 days in IMNCI 4 days of training and two weeks of observership
Staff 1 doctor, 1 nurse, 1 auxiliary midwife 1 doctor, 4 nurses 3-4 doctors and 10 nurses

questions.text: A child was weaned off of breastmilk by 3 months of age which caused severe malnutrition and recurrent infections. This falls under which ecological factor of malnutrition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario showing early curtailment of breastfeeding causing malnutrition is one example of child-rearing practices that leads to malnutrition.

Ecology of Malnutrition :

The ecological factors related to malnutrition as follows 

  1. Conditioning influences: A conditioning factor that plays a huge role in malnutrition is infectious diseases which causes a vicious cycle where infections cause malnutrition which in turn causes minor childhood ailments. Diarrhoeal diseases, intestinal parasites, measles, whooping cough, malaria, tuberculosis contributes significantly to malnutrition. The occurrence of infections are largely based on the environmental conditions that the child is exposed to.
  2. Cultural influences: Poor diets as a result of cultural and regional influences also play a role in malnutrition. They are as follows with an example for each:
    • Food habits, traditions, customs, beliefs and attitudes: Rice and wheat are largely staple in India. Papaya is avoided as it is thought to cause abortion.
    • Religion: Hindus do not eat beef and Muslims do not eat pork.
    • Food fads: Personal likes and dislikes to a certain group of foods.
    • Cooking practices: Prolonged boiling of cereals in open pans which leads to a loss of nutritive value
    • Child-rearing practices: Premature curtailment of breastfeeding
  3. Socio-economic factors: Poverty plays a huge role in causing malnutrition. This is usually a result of ignorance, insufficient education, lack of knowledge regarding the nutritive value of foods, inadequate sanitary environment, large family size, etc. which affects the quality of life.
  4. Food production: The amount of food produced is directly proportional to the amount of food consumed. Developed countries have 5.8 hectares of arable land compared to the 0.6 hectares of land per Indian. Even distribution of food among all sectors of society is also a factor.
  5. Health and other services: Remedial actions that can be taken by the health sector to reduce malnutrition are as follows - 
    • Nutritional surveillance - Continuous monitoring of factors that affect nutrition; groups affected are identified.
    • Nutritional rehabilitation - Urgent care for individuals suffering from severe malnutrition.
    • Nutrition supplementation - Supplementary feeds for mothers and children
    • Health education - Health education programmes to increase awareness about malnutrition and nutrition value of food.

questions.text: As part of a research program, a community is being tested by three screening tests for COVID-19. The patient is considered diseased if he/she tests positive in any one of the screening tests. Which of the following is false about this pattern of screening?
questions.solution:
The given scenario shows a number of screening tests being conducted in parallel, where the net specificity is low. 

The combination of two or more tests performed together can help to enhance the efficacy of detecting the presence or absence of disease. There are two principal forms of combination of tests:

Screening tests used in series:

  • If a patient is considered to have a disease when he is positive by every test conducted, then the tests are said to be in series.
  • If the patient tests negative in any one or more of the tests, they are classified as non-diseased.
  • It is thus difficult to classify a patient as diseased and easier to classify a patient as non-diseased.
  • This increases the number of false negatives.

Screening tests used in parallel:

  • Tests are said to be in parallel when a positive result on any one or more tests is considered sufficient to classify a patient into the diseased group.
  • A subject is considered nondiseased only when they test negative by all the tests.
  • Hence, some without disease are more likely to be wrongly classified into the diseased group, but many without disease are correctly excluded.
  Tests in Series Tests in parallel
Combined sensitivity Decreases Increases
Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases Increases

questions.text: A physician is studying parameter x. She checks the parameter x of all patients using an automated apparatus and compares them to manual checking (considered by her as the gold standard). For patient A, she finds that the automated apparatus and manual checking give very different values. However, on checking 5 times with the automated apparatus, all 5 values obtained are similar to each other. What can be concluded about the automated apparatus?
questions.solution:
The automated apparatus has low validity (accuracy) but high precision.

Validity (accuracy) refers to what extent the test accurately measures which it sets out to measure. It refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values. The values obtained by the automated apparatus are very different from the true values, reducing the validity of the automated apparatus readings.

Precision (reliability or reproducibility) is a measure of repeatability of a test. That is, the test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under the same conditions. The 5 values obtained by the automated apparatus are close to each other, making it precise.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: What is the aim of the Alma-Ata Declaration (1978)?
questions.solution:
Universal access to primary healthcare is the aim of the Alma-Ata Declaration (1978).

A new approach to healthcare came into existence in 1978, following an international conference at Alma-Ata. This is known as "primary health care". 

The Alma-Ata international conference gave primary health care a wider meaning. The Alma-Ata conference defined primary health care as - 
"Primary health care is essential health care made universally accessible to individuals and acceptable to them, through their full participation and at a cost the community and country can afford". 

Primary health care has been accepted as an integral part of the country's health system in all countries. The Alma-Ata Declaration has outlined 8 elements of primary health care.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: Which of the following is a low-cost pour-flush, water-seal type of latrine consisting of a pan and water seal trap connected to a 3-foot-deep square pit, where excreta is converted into manure?
questions.solution:
The "Sulabh Shauchalaya" model is a low-cost pour-flush, water-seal type of latrine that is being used in many parts of India.

It is an improved version of the standard hand flush latrine (e.g., RCA type). It consists of a specially designed pan and a water-seal trap connected to a square pit 3 feet deep. Excreta undergoes bacterial decomposition and is converted to manure (compost). The method requires very little water. Delhi has opted for this system in all its slums.

Methods of excreta disposal:

1. Unsewered areas:

  • Service-type latrines (conservancy system): In this system, nightsoil is collected manually from pail or bucket-type latrines and then disposed of by burying or composting.
  • Non-service type latrines (sanitary latrines): Borehole latrines, dug well or pit latrines, water-seal latrines (P.R.A.I. type, R.C.A. type, and Sulabh shauchalaya) septic tanks, aqua privy.
  • Latrines for camps and temporary use: Shallow and deep trench latrines, pit latrines, and borehole latrines.

2. Sewered areas: Water carriage system and sewage treatment

  • Primary treatment – Screening, removal of grit, and plain sedimentation
  • Secondary treatment – Trickling filters, activated sludge process
  • Other methods – sea and river outfalls, sewage farming, oxidation ponds

Other Options:

Option A: The service type or conservancy system type latrines comprise of collection and removal of nightsoil from bucket or pail latrines by human agencies. The nightsoil is then transported in "nightsoil carts" to the place of final disposal, where it is disposed off by (i) composting or (ii) burial in shallow trenches. 

Option B:  In the zero discharge toilet system, a separator divides the liquid component ( urine and flushed water) and redirects it into an outward tank. The solid part in the form of slurry is dropped into another chamber called a retention tank. The solid and liquid parts are separated, collected, and reused.

Option C: The aqua privy is a water-filled chamber with a drop pipe that receives excreta and is a simplified version of the septic tank.

questions.text: Which of the following indices is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake?
questions.solution:
Net protein utilization (NPU) is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake.

NPU is calculated as the percentage of protein retained by the body from the total protein intake. It is described as the product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value multiplied by 100.

1 gram of protein is equivalent to 6.25 g of nitrogen. The NPU value of a dietary protein and the protein requirement of the individual are inversely related to each other. The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Other options:

Option A: Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the ratio of milligrams of digestible dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the dietary protein to the milligrams of the same dietary indispensable amino acid in 1 gram of the reference protein. 

Option C: The biological value is calculated as the amount of nitrogen used for tissue formation divided by the nitrogen absorbed from food expressed in percentage. It is a reflection of essential amino acid supplied and a measure of protein quality. 

Option D: The amino acid score refers to the concentration of each essential amino acid in the test protein. It is calculated as the percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: According to the accepted standard for overcrowding, which among the following is considered an overcrowded house?

choices.text: A couple, with their 6-year-old kid, living in a house with 2 rooms
A couple, with their two kids aged 11 and 13 years old, living in a house with 2 rooms
A couple, with a 6-month-old baby, living in a house with a single-room
A couple, with their two kids aged 4 and 6 years old, living in a house with 2 rooms

questions.solution:
A couple (husband and wife), with their two kids of 11 years and 13 years old, living in a house with two rooms is considered to be an overcrowded house.

Overcrowding occurs when a house has more people than it can accommodate, leading to limited space, privacy, hygiene, and sleep. 

Infectious diseases spread rapidly in overcrowded conditions, promoting the transmission of respiratory infections such as tuberculosis, influenza, and diphtheria. High morbidity and mortality rates are observed in areas with substandard housing conditions.

Children 1-10 years are counted as half a unit while a baby under 12 months is not counted (Option C).

Overcrowding is considered to exist if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband and wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

The accepted standards against overcrowding are as follows.

No of rooms  No of persons
1 room 2 persons
2 rooms 3 persons
3 rooms 5 persons
4 rooms 7 persons
5 rooms 10 persons (1 room for every 2 additional persons)

The floor space standards against overcrowding are as follows.

Area No of persons
110 sq. ft. and more 2 persons
90 – 100 sq. ft. 1 ½ persons (Children from 1 – 10 are counted as a half unit)
70 – 90 sq. ft. 1 person
50 – 70 sq. ft. ½ person

questions.text: The measures that are taken to prevent a disaster from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are a part of _______.
questions.solution:
The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation also includes measures taken to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

Other options:

Option A - Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.

Option B - Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

Option C - Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities, which include the development of policies or programs for disaster management prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is well prepared to face any future disasters, and effectively prevent or manage to reduce the impact.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the primary health center to avail of a contraceptive provided under a new government program. She does not want to take daily pills. She was started on the contraceptive shown in the image below.  Which of the following drugs is used in this?
questions.solution:
Injectable contraceptive medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) is introduced under the Antara program.

The dosage is 150 mg I.M every 3 months. This injectable contraceptive is not to be refrigerated. It is to be stored always at room temperature (15-30 degree centigrade).

Mechanism of action:

  • Inhibition of ovulation
  • Cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration
  • Endometrial atrophy preventing implantation.

The first dose can be taken: 

  • Anytime after regular menstruation, or 
  • After 6 weeks of delivery, or 
  • Immediately after abortion

This injectable contraceptive should not be given to a woman with:

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding 
  • Stroke or severe diabetes
  • Breast cancer (past/present)
  • Active hepatitis or liver tumor
  • A desire for rapid return to fertility

Disadvantages

  • Menstrual irregularities: Light / heavy bleeding or amenorrhoea
  • Slight weight gain
  • No protection against HIV/STDs 
  • A slight loss in BMD during the first 2 years of use

Note:

Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were recently launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A cut-out picture of hygiene practices was attached to a khadi fixed over a wooden board through sandpaper at the back of the cut-out and displayed to the village school children. How would you categorise this method of health communication?
questions.solution:
A cut-out picture of hygiene practices attached to a khadi fixed over a wooden board through sandpaper at the back of the cut-out is a flannelgraph, which is an audio-visual aid in the Chalk and talk (lecture) method of health communication.

The health communication method used in the above scenario is the chalk-and-talk approach, commonly known as lectures.

Lectures in health communication fall under the category of group approaches, typically involving gatherings of up to 30 individuals and lasting between 15 to 20 minutes. It is usually combined with audio-visual aids to make the sessions more effective like: 

  • Flipcharts
  • Flannelgraph
  • Exhibits
  • Films and charts 

The disadvantages of this approach are : 

  • Students involved to a minimum extent
  • Learning is passive
  • Health behaviour is not necessarily affected 

Other options:

Option A: Posters are intended to catch the eye and create awareness and come under the mass media method of Health communication.

Option B: Demonstration:  A method of teaching or presenting information where actions, processes, or techniques are shown to an audience to illustrate how something works or how to perform a task or a procedure. 

Option C: Health Exhibition is a form of mass media where knowledge is presented in the form of various ideas.

 Methods of Health Communication    
 Individual approach  Group approach  Mass approach
  1. Personal contact
  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1.  Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Roleplay
  1.  TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

questions.text: A 23-year-old male from Andhra Pradesh presented with features of cervical stenosis and a strikingly noticeable genu-valgum. The radiograph of his forearms appears as given below. Personal history reveals his staple diet as jowar. How would this diet affect the fluoride levels in his body to cause this presentation?

choices.text: High fluoride levels by inhibiting urinary excretion
Low fluoride levels by promoting urinary excretion
High fluoride levels by increasing ingested fluoride retention
Low fluoride levels by decreasing ingested fluoride retention

questions.solution:
The given history of Genu valgum and the image showing interosseous membrane ossification is characteristic of fluorosis. It is seen in people consuming jawar(sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Fluorosis is seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L

Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.

This leads to impaired mineralization and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

The characteristic pathology involves sub-periosteal new bone formation, osteosclerosis (most commonly seen in vertebrae, ribs, and pelvis), and hyperostosis at the bony attachments of ligaments, tendons, and fascia. 

Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament can also be seen, usually after the age of 50 years. It is associated with various bone-forming conditions such as diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) and fluorosis. It is most commonly seen in the cervical spine.  It can result in spinal stenosis and cervical myelopathy causing pain and weakness in the limbs. X-ray shows dense ossification along the back of the vertebral bodies in the mid-cervical spine. 

Note: Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the percentage of disease-free people being correctly identified as healthy by a test?
questions.solution:
Specificity represents the percentage of disease-free people being correctly identified as healthy by a test.

It is given by the formula:

Specificity = (Number testing positive who do not have the disease / total number tested who do not have the disease ) ×100 

  Specificity Negative predictive value
Given by    TN     
FP + TN		    TN     
FN + TN
Numerator

TN- The number of healthy people correctly identified by the given test

TN- The number of healthy people correctly identified by the given test
Denominator FP+TN= The actual number of healthy people (as identified by the gold standard test) FN+TN= The total number of people tested negative by the given test
  Compares the number of true negatives detected by the test among the people who actually do not have the disease. Compares the actual number of true negatives among the people who tested negative according to the given test 

Other options: 

Option A - Sensitivity of test is the percentage of people with a disease who are correctly detected or classified.

Option C - Positive predictive value of a test is the proportion of positive results that are true positives, that is, the likelihood that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease.

Option D - Negative predictive value is the proportion of negative results that are true negatives.

The negative predictive value of a test compares the actual number of disease-free people (obtained from gold standard test) to the number of people who tested disease-free by the given test.

It represents the likelihood that a person with a negative result truly does not have the disease. It reflects the number of tests that have correctly identified a person to be free of the disease.

Note: True positives and true negatives are identified based on the gold standard test for the given condition.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A researcher wants to survey the general population of a country. For this, he draws the sample in a systematic way so that each portion of the sample represents a corresponding strata of the population. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.solution:
In this study, stratified random sampling method is used where the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups where each group represents a corresponding strata of the population.

Related Pearl: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

  • In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.
  • Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.

2. Stratified random sampling

  • In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.
  • For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.

3. Cluster sampling

  • In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.
  • In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.
  • This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.
  • This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.
  • Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.
  • Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.

4. Systematic random sampling

  • In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.
  • For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text:
Under the ESI Act, the covered employees contribution to the fund from the daily wages is:

ESI - Employees State Insurance
questions.solution:
The ESI is a self-financing insurance scheme in which the covered employees contribute 0.75% of the wages, whereas, the employers contribute 3.25% of the wages, payable to their employees.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: What is McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate?
questions.solution:
McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate is 4.5 L/4 hours.

This is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with the normal physiological reaction of acclimatized, healthy young men who are exposed to heat. The predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR) is obtained from readings of air and mean radiant temperature and air velocity under different work intensities. Based on this value, the zone of comfort can be determined.

Zone of comfort    Predicted P4SR
Comfort zone 1–3 liters
Just tolerable 3–4.5 liters
Intolerable 4.5+ liters

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demography of a village with a population of 10,000. In the total population, 1000 members were found to be below 15 years of age and 1000 members were over 65 years of age. What is the total dependency ratio of this population?
questions.solution:
The total dependency ratio in this population is 25%.

This can be calculated using the given formula:

Here, the total population below 15 years of age is = 1000

Total population above 65 years of age = 1000

So, total population between 15-64 years of age = 10,000 - (1000 + 1000) = 8,000

Hence, the dependency ratio in this population = (2,000 X 100) ÷ 8,000 = 25%

questions.text: After the chemotherapy session for breast carcinoma, your senior asks you to discard empty vials of paclitaxel. Which of the following bins will you discard them in?
questions.solution:
Used, discarded, and expired cytotoxic drugs, whether in plastic vacutainers, syringes, glass vials, ampoules, or glass bottles, along with the items used during the administration of cytotoxic drugs, like IV sets, gloves, dressing, and cotton swabs, are discarded into the yellow bin with cytotoxic label.

Paclitaxel is a cytotoxic drug used as a part of a regimen in breast cancer chemotherapy.

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, except those contaminated with cytotoxic wastes are discarded in blue bins.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the stage of the demographic cycle that India is currently in?

choices.text: Birth rate lower than the death rate
Declining death rate and declining birth rate
High birth rate and high death rate
Declining death rate and birth rate remains unchanged

questions.solution:
India is currently in the "late expanding" stage which is the third stage in the demographic cycle where declining death rates and declining birth rates are seen.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

UN Data (2021)

  • India’s population was 1,393,409,000 (1.39 Billion) 
  • In 2021, India ranked 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2020)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 28 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.5
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

questions.text:
A study compares the effectiveness of two contraceptive methods after exposing the subjects for a year. What is the Pearl Index for each method?

Method A: 100 women, 2 accidental pregnancies.

Method B: 100 women, 5 accidental pregnancies.

choices.text: Method A: 0.2, Method B: 0.5, Contraceptive A better than B
Method A: 0.2, Method B: 0.5, Contraceptive B better than A
Method A: 2, Method B: 5, Contraceptive A better than B
Method A: 2, Method B: 5, Contraceptive B better than A

questions.solution:
For the given scenario, contraceptive method A with a pearl index of 2 is better than contraceptive method B with a pearl index of 5.

The Pearl index is the common method used to measure contraceptive failure rate. It is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). This rate is given by the formula:

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Here, in method A, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 2 and 100 women are exposed to the method. In method B, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 5 and 100 women are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 12 months(a year) x 100 = 1200.

Hence, the Pearl index of Method A = 2 x 1200/1200 = 2 per HWY. 

Pearl index of Method B = 5 x 1200/1200 = 5 per HWY.

Therefore, contraceptive method A with a pearl index of 2 is better than contraceptive method B with a pearl index of 5, since the smaller the Pearl Index, the safer the method of contraception.

In the numerator, the total accidental pregnancies include every conception, irrespective of the outcome, such as live births, stillbirths or abortions. The factor 1200 is the number of months in 100 years. The total months of exposure to the contraceptive method is the denominator, calculated by subtracting 10 months for a full-term pregnancy and 4 months for an abortion.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of septic tank?

choices.text: Aerobic oxidation takes place outside the tank
Desludging must be done at least once a year

questions.solution:
The ideal retention period for a septic tank is 24 hours.

If the retention period is too short, there is insufficient treatment of sewage and if it is too long, then undue septicity results.

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

Below is an image of a double-chambered septic tank.

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management, what is the appropriate method of treatment for the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
The appropriate method of treatment of the intraosseous needle, shown in the image, is autoclaving.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutters or burners, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause punctures and cuts are disposed of in white, translucent, puncture-proof, and leak-proof containers. They are treated by autoclaving/ dry heat sterilization followed by - shredding/mutilation/encapsulation and later sent to iron foundries/sanitary landfills.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

The image given below shows an autoclave.

The biomedical waste management rule applies to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose, and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorized and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then treated by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration (Option B)- this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection (Option D)- chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes. 
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process. 
  • Microwave irradiation (Option A) - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely.

Later disposed of by -

  • Iron foundries/sanitary landfill
  • Inertization: Waste is mixed with cement to reduce toxicity.

However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: A new screening test for detecting cervical cancer is being studied in a group of 100 women.  60 women tested negative and 40 tested positive.  Among the women who tested positive by the new test, 30 were positive and among the women who tested negative, 10 were having the disease. What is the positive predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value is 75%

The data given in the question is tabulated as follows:

  Diseased Not diseased Total
Test positive 30 (TP) 10 (FP) 40
Test negative 10 (FN) 50 (TN) 60
Total 40 60 100

TP - True positive, FP - False positive, FN - False negative, TN - True negative.

Positive predictive value (PPV) = TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

Here PPV = 30/(30+10) x 100 = 30/40 x 100 = 75%

Predictive value of a positive test:

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease. Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. It is highly related to the prevalence of a disease. The predictive value of a positive test will be more accurate if the disease is more prevalent and vice-versa.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: In a given population, the chance of developing a particular cancer was found to be 40%. What is the probability that all 4 randomly selected people from the population would have cancer?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the probability of all 4 randomly selected people getting cancer would be 0.0256.

The probability of a person developing cancer in the population is given by p (developing cancer) = 40/100 = 0.4

If 4 people are randomly selected in a population, the chance of the first person having cancer is independent of the second/third/fourth also having it and vice-versa. This satisfies the condition for the multiplication rule of probability. It states that the probability of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is equal to the product of their individual probabilities.

Hence in this scenario, the probability that all 4 randomly selected people from the population would have cancer = 0.4 x 0.4 x 0.4 x 0.4 = 0.0256

Note: The (p) of any one of the 4 randomly selected people from the population having cancer = the sum of their individual probabilities = 0.4 + 0.4 + 0.4 + 0.4 = 1.6

Related Pearl: Probability

  • Expressed as a decimal fraction never as a percentage. Denoted by p
  • Must lie between 0 (zero probability) and 1 (absolute certainty).
  • Probability of an event cannot be negative.
  • The probability of an event not occurring (q) is q= 1-p

Rule

Description

Example

The Addition Rule

(p) of any one of several particular events occurring = the sum of their individual probabilities, provided the events cannot both happen and are mutually exclusive.

Probability of picking a heart card from a deck is 0.25 and that of picking a club is 0.25. Thus the p (hearts or clubs) is 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.50.

The Multiplication Rule

(p) of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is = product of their individual probabilities.

If the lifetime probability of a person developing a lung neoplasm is 0.25 and the life time probability of developing dementia is 0.01, then the p (lung neoplasm and dementia) is 0.25 x 0.01 = 0.0025.

The Binomial Distribution

 

(p) of the occurrence of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events.

The events for which binomial distribution is used have only two outcomes like yes or no, tall or short, male or female, etc.

 

Widely used in genetic counseling.

questions.text: A new test has been developed to screen for ovarian cancer. The following figure illustrates the distribution of values for this test among two populations. If the researcher chooses values under 30 µg/dL as normal limits for the test, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Some persons without cancer will test positive
All persons with cancer will have a positive test

questions.solution:
The test will be 100% specific as nobody without the disease (i.e. nobody that is within the normal range) would test positive.

There is an overlapping of the normal population and the population with the disease for most screening tests which leads to a compromise between sensitivity and specificity of the test. 

The interval 0 μg/dL to 30 μg/dL includes all values of the normal population, but also some values of the population with cancer; therefore, no value above 30 μg/dL will occur in individuals without the disease.  At this cut-off, the test will be 100% specific.
Some individuals with cancer are missed as they have values between 20 μg/dL and 30 μg/dL.

If the interval of 0 μg/dL to 25 μg/dL is chosen, then some persons with levels above 25 μg will have cancer and others will not. There will be some persons without cancer who will test positive (false-positives) and some persons with cancer will test negative (false-negatives).

The interval of 0 μg/dL to 20 μg/dL will be 100% sensitive as it will detect all cancers: there will be no false-negative tests. The compromise here is that it will be less specific: some persons without cancer will test positive (false positive). Therefore, some confirmation of the test by another more specific method will be necessary before we can draw any conclusion. 

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms develop after consumption of mustard oil contaminated with argemone oil?

choices.text: Non-inflammatory, bilateral pitting edema with diarrhoea
Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs

questions.solution:
Argemone oil contains a toxic alkaloid sanguinarine which causes epidemic dropsy. Symptoms include non-inflammatory, bilateral pitting edema associated with diarrhea. 

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure. Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

Other options -

Option B: Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, and peripheral gangrene are caused by the consumption of ergot-infested grain leading to ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus.  Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Option C: Rapidly developing ascites and jaundice are associated with the consumption of millets contaminated with weed seeds of Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia which contain a toxic pyrrolizidine alkaloid and produce symptoms of endemic ascites that manifest as rapidly developing ascites and jaundice. 

Option D: Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs is associated with the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus leading to neurolathyrism. 

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism.

Disease   Food Substance  Toxic Principle  Clinical features
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus /Khesari dal  BOAA (beta oxalyl amino alanine) Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine  Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Acute- Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness
Chronic- Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids  Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice

(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation with bleeding per vagina had a miscarriage. The products of conception are sent for appropriate tests. Which of the following is not a disposal option for the same?
questions.solution:
Encapsulation is not a disposal option for human anatomical waste. It is a disposal technique used for expired and discarded medicines along with chemical wastes. 

Human anatomical waste such as an aborted fetus is put in a yellow bag and is disposed of by either incineration, plasma pyrolysis, or deep burial. 

The biomedical waste management rule is applicable to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorised and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then disposed of by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration - this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection - chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes. 
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process. 
  • Microwave irradiation - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely. 
  • Land disposal - either municipal disposal sites or sanitary landfills are used. 
  • Inertization - waste is mixed with cement and other substances before disposal to reduce toxicity. 

Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas which lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. Permission from the concerned authority is needed and guidelines issued by the central pollution control board should be followed. 

Cytotoxic and biohazard materials will have separate non-washable and visible symbols as shown below:
