questions.text: The GOBI-FFF strategy, which is aimed at revolutionizing child health care, was given by _______.
questions.solution:
The GOBI-FFF strategy was given by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF).

The GOBI-FFF strategy is aimed at child health revolution and survival. It was initially called the GOBI strategy, and the FFF aspect was later added to it.

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

Related Pearl: Organizations and their Headquarters

Related Pearl: World Health Organization

  • It is a specialized, non-political health agency of the United Nations.
  • The headquarters of WHO is in Geneva, Switzerland.
  • It came into force on 7th April, 1948.
  • Objective: The attainment by all people of the highest level of health.
  • Structure of the WHO: The World Health Assembly, the Executive Board, and the Secretariat.
  • Work of the WHO:
    • Prevention and control of specific diseases
    • Development of comprehensive health services
    • Family health
    • Environmental health
    • Health statistics
    • Biomedical research
    • Health literature and information
    • Cooperation with other organizations
  • Regional offices of the WHO:
    • South East Asian office is in New Delhi, India
    • African regional office is in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo.
    • Regional office of the Americas is in Washington D. C., USA.
    • European regional head office is in Copenhagen, Denmark.
    • Eastern Mediterranean office is in Alexandria, Egypt.
    • Western Pacific regional office is in Manila, Philippines.
  • The South East Asia Regional Office (SEARO) of the WHO is in New Delhi.
  • Activities like malaria eradication, tuberculosis control and rural health services are the activities conducted here.

questions.text: Which of the following is not among the leading causes of death in the 1-4 years age group in countries with the below population pyramid?
questions.solution:
The given population pyramid shows a bulge in the middle and has a narrower base and is suggestive of developed countries. Diarrheal disease is not a leading cause of death in the 1-4 years age group in developed countries. All the other options are the leading causes of death in this group. 

Accidental deaths are the leading cause of death from the age of one year in developed countries, while deaths from infectious diseases are quite rare. Identified groups of home accidents are:

  • Fall from unprotected stairs and balconies
  • Suffocation
  • Burns and scalds
  • Poisoning

Most accidents are preventable. Other leading causes are congenital anomalies and malignant neoplasms. These are not easy to prevent or cure.

A population pyramid with a broad base and a tapering top is typical of developing countries. Diarrheal disease, respiratory infection followed by communicable diseases like whooping cough and measles are the leading cause of death in 1-4 years of age children in developing countries. When these diseases are combined with malnutrition, they have high case fatality rates.

Leading cause of death in 1-4 years of age group
Developing countries Developed countries
Diarrhea Accidents
Respiratory infection Congenital anomalies
Malnutrition Malignant neoplasm
Infectious diseases Influenza
Febrile disease Pneumonia
Accidents and injuries  

 

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the Schmutzdecke layer in a slow sand filter?

choices.text: It forms on the bottom  of the filter bed and acts as a biological barrier.
It is primarily composed of alum and acts as a physical barrier.
It is primarily composed of sand particles and acts as a physical barrier.
It forms on the surface  of the filter bed and acts as a biological barrier.

questions.solution:
Schmutzdecke layer forms on the surface of the filter bed and acts as a biological barrier in a slow sand filter.

Other options

Option B: Alum is a chemical coagulant used in rapid sand filters as a physical barrier.

Option C: Sand particles act as physical barriers in both slow as well as rapid sand filters.

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

questions.text:
The population statistics of a country are being predicted. According to the Malthusian growth model, if a country's _______ is 1%, then the population will double in ______.

AGR - Annual Growth Rate
TFR - Total Fertility Rate
questions.solution:
As per the Malthusian growth model, when the annual growth rate is 1%, the population doubles in 70 years.

The Malthusian growth model/rule of 70:

Rating Annual growth rate Population doubles in
Slow growth <0.5% >139 years
Moderate growth 0.5-1% ~139 years
Rapid growth 1-1.5% 70 years
Very rapid growth 1.5-2% approximately 50 years
Explosive growth 2-2.5% 35 years
Explosive growth 3-3.5% 20-25 years

The growth rate of India is estimated at 1% as per 2020 UN data. Therefore, it falls in the rapidly growing phase of population growth.

questions.text: In reverse triage, priority is given to which among the following?
questions.solution:
In reverse triage, priority is given to patients with green color coding, which consists of ambulatory patients.

Reverse triage is a method to redistribute resources to those patients who need them most by identifying the least critical patients who require the least amount of resources.  Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more.

This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment. It is also done when medical resources are scarce after a disaster.

The surge capacity of hospitals is increased to accommodate for the natural disaster, by discharging non-emergent existing patients. This enables hospitals to allow for an acute increase in incoming patients.

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby through the cesarean section and returns home after 5 days. How many visits should an ASHA worker make post delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, an ASHA worker would make 5 visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother.

The woman delivers a baby through the cesarean section and returns home after 5 days. The ASHA worker should ideally make the first visit on day 7 and, thereafter, 4 visits till day 42.

Home visits of ASHA workers post delivery:

  • 7 visits after home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 5 visits after cesarean section delivery, first visit on day 7, and thereafter 4 visits till day 42

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text:
Match the following methods of graphical representations with the appropriate types of data presented using them.
Graphs Type of data
1) Frequency polygons a) Nominal data
2) Histogram b) Interval scale data
3) Bar charts c) Trend of events over time
4) Line diagram d) Continous data
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Graphs Type of data
1) Frequency polygons

b) Interval scale data
2) Histogram

d) Continous data
3) Bar charts

a) Nominal data
4) Line diagram

c) Trend of events over time


Frequency polygons are formed by joining the midpoints of histogram blocks. It is used to represent ratio or interval scale data.

Histogram is a pictorial representation of frequency distribution and is formed by a series of blocks. It is used to represent a continuous group or data. The area under each block is proportional to the frequency.

Bar charts are used to depict nominal scale data. The length of the bar in the diagram is proportional to the magnitude that is represented. It can be simple, multiple, or component bar graphs.

A line diagram is used to depict the trends of events over a period of time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: The life table analysis calculated under Reproductive and Child Health program in a district is done for assessing:
questions.solution:
The life table analysis is done to assess the efficacy of contraceptives. 

Contraceptive efficacy is generally assessed by two methods - the pearl index and life table analysis.

  • Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).
  • Life table analysis calculates a failure rate for each month of use. A cumulative failure rate can then compare methods for any length of exposure. 

Option A: Net Reproduction Rate is calculated to assess the reproductive performance of the population. If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate. It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.  NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2-child norm.

Option B: The Couple Protection Rate is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community. It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

Option D: An unmet need for family planning refers to a situation where sexually active individuals, particularly women, want to avoid pregnancy but are not using any contraceptive methods.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: This booklet by the CDC is related to:
questions.solution:
The shown booklet by the CDC is related to emporiatrics.

Emporiatics is a term used to describe the study of the health of travelers. Travelers encounter unique health risks, especially in the era of jet travel. International travelers often experience various stressors that can weaken their immune response, such as overcrowding, lengthy waiting times, disruptions in eating patterns, and changes in climate and time zones. These factors can lead to symptoms like nausea, indigestion, severe fatigue, and insomnia.

Travelers are recommended prophylactics and vaccines when going to areas with specific endemic diseases.

Other options:

Option A: Nosology is defined more specifically as a scientific classification system for diseases or disorders.

Option B: Ergonomics is the study of matching job requirements and environment to the worker to maximize efficiency, quality, and quantity of work while minimizing work-related musculoskeletal disorders, fatigue, and overexertion.

Option D: Epornithic is a term used for epidemic in bird populations.

questions.text: Data about recent trends of immunization of children in the community can be found by:
questions.solution:
Data about recent trends of immunization in the community can be found in district surveys.

The RCH program conducts district-based rapid household surveys to assess the reproductive health status of women. It includes

  • Percentage of pregnant women with full ANC
  • Percentage of institutional deliveries and home deliveries
  • Percentage of home deliveries by the trained birth attendant
  • The current contraceptive prevalence rate
  • Percentage of children fully immunized
  • Percentage of unmet needs for family planning
  • Percentage of household reported visits by a health worker in previous 3 months.

questions.text: As a demographer, you are asked to study the demographic trends in India. You divide the demographic indicators into population statistics and vital statistics. Which of the following is not included in the vital statistics?
questions.solution:
Sex ratio is a part of population statistics. Birth rate, life expectancy at birth, and fertility rates are part of vital statistics.

Demographic characteristics give an overview of the population's size, composition, geographical distribution, trends, and components of change such as nativity, mortality, and social mobility.

Demographic indicators are split into two categories: population statistics and vital statistics.

  • Population statistics include indicators that measure the population size, sex ratio, density, and dependency ratio.
  • Vital statistics include indicators such as birth rate, death rate, natural growth rate, life expectancy at birth, mortality, and fertility rates.

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

UN Data (2021)

  • India’s population was 1,393,409,000 (1.39 Billion) 
  • In 2021, India ranked 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2020)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 28 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.5
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

questions.text: The number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate is called:
questions.solution:
The number of daughters a newborn girl will bear in her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates is called Net Reproductive Ratio (NRR).

NRR is a demographic indicator and NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately attaining the 2-child norm in India. If the NRR is less than one, it indicates that the reproductive capacity of the population is below the replacement level.

Other options:

Option A- Gross reproductive rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Option C- Total fertility rate is the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass-through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women now in each age group.

Option D- General fertility rate is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: You join a dedicated COVID health center where pediatric cases are prioritized and monitored on the basis of the patient's body temperature. A compilation of the temperature readings (in Celsius) of all the patients arranged in a meaningful order represents data in which of the following scales of measurement?
questions.solution:
The temperature readings (in celsius) of the patients represent interval scale data.

Similar to ordinal data, interval scale data can be placed in a meaningful order, but in addition, the items have meaningful intervals between them, which are usually measured quantities. In the given scenario, the temperatures of the patients can be arranged from high to low and the difference between the temperatures of each patient is quantifiable in measured quantities. This scale of measurement does not have an absolute zero; hence, the ratios of the scores are not meaningful.

All data can be measured in one of four scales—nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scale (mnemonic: NOIR).

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text:
In a rural area in the state of Uttar Pradesh, a primigravida goes for institutional delivery after being motivated by an ASHA worker. What are the benefits they will receive (in terms of money in rupees) under the Janani Suraksha Yojana?

ASHA- Accredited social health activist
questions.solution:
According to Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) scheme, the mother will receive 1400 rupees and the ASHA worker will receive 600 rupees.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), whose aim is to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

The Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is the link between pregnant women and health institutions. She is responsible for making institutional antenatal and postnatal care available. 

States are divided into low-performing and high-performing on the basis of institutional delivery rate. The 10 low-performing states (LPS) with a low institutional delivery rate are Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, Bihar, Rajasthan, Chattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, and Jammu & Kashmir. All the other states are high-performing states (HPS).

The incentives under JSY are as follows:

Category  Rural area Urban area
LPS

Mother package: 1400/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:2000/-

 Mother package: 1000/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1400/-
HPS Mother package: 700/-
ASHA's package:600/-
Total:1300/-		 Mother package: 600/-
ASHA's package:400/-
Total:1000/-

Under this scheme, the cost of cesarean section and management of obstetric complications is also subsidized, up to Rs 1500 per delivery to the government institutions, where government specialists are not present.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient with increased blood pressure has come to the outpatient department. He asks about lifestyle modifications and a DASH diet was suggested. How much does the systolic blood pressure drop by adopting the DASH diet?

DASH: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension
questions.solution:
The systolic blood pressure drops by 8-14 mmHg by adopting the DASH diet.

DASH is a diet plan which involves consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced fat content. 

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension and the reduction in blood pressure are shown below.

Modification Impact on SBP
Weight reduction to maintain a normal body mass index 5–20 mmHg per 10kg weight loss
DASH diet 8–14 mmHg
Sodium intake reduction (< 6 grams of sodium chloride) 2–8 mmHg
Physical activity: 30 minutes of a brisk walk per day  4–9 mmHg

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Hypertension is a preventable disease. There are two approaches:

  • Primary prevention - includes measures that are taken to reduce the incidence by reducing the risk of onset. Population strategies are dietary modification, weight reduction, and exercise. A high-risk strategy prevents the shooting of blood pressure which might need institutional treatment.
  • Secondary prevention - includes the detection and usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. 

Related Pearl: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

Indication

Initial treatment of choice 

Hypertension alone or hypertension with diabetes/ cerebrovascular disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with coronary artery disease

ACEi/ ARB + beta blocker/CCB (A+B or A+C)

or

beta-blocker + diuretic (B+D)

or 

CCB+ diuretic/ beta-blocker (C+B or C+D)

Hypertension with chronic kidney disease

ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D)

Hypertension with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction

ACEI/ ARB + diuretic + beta-blocker (A+D+B)

Pregnancy

Labetalol, Nifedipine, methyldopa

ACEi – Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

ARB – Angiotensin II receptor blockers

CCB – Calcium Channel Blockers

Related Pearl: Classification of blood pressure for adults - European Society of Cardiology guidelines - 2018

Note: Whenever hypertension can be classified into two different categories based on values of SBP and DBP, then the higher category is considered as the classification of hypertension.

questions.text: A villager presents to you saying that his friends have been telling him to not eat the dal in the picture below, because it will cause paralysis. He is economically weak and wants to continue eating it. Which of the following methods will you not recommend to prevent the complication caused by this dal?

choices.text: Good amount of ascorbic acid in the diet
Removing the husk of the dal
Soaking the dal in limewater overnight and then boiling
Limiting the amount of dal to a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed per day

questions.solution:
The given history and the image showing triangular and greyish dal are suggestive of khesari dal – Lathyrus sativus. Removing the husk of the dal is not a method used to remove the toxin present in it.

Khesari dal has a toxin known as beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA). This toxin is water soluble. The dal must be consumed in large quantities for a period of 2-3 months before the toxin starts having any clinical effect.

Long-term consumption of khesari dal leads to neurolathyrism. It is characterized by gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. The patient is initially able to walk with short jerky steps without any aids, but the progressive spastic paralysis causes a crossed gait, and the patient has to use sticks to maintain his balance. Eventually, the knee joints are unable to support the weight of the body and the patient cannot stand erect at all.

The interventions that can be used to prevent lathyrism include:
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis (option A)
  • Limiting the proportion of the dal to less than a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed in a day (option D)
  • Removal of the toxin by:
    • Parboiling: this involves soaking the dal in limewater overnight and then boiling it (option C).
    • Steeping method: this involves soaking the dal in hot water for a period of 2 hours. The dal is then washed with cleaned water and dried before consumption.

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Food Adulterant Toxin Disease
Dal Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) BOAA* Lathyrism
Oil Argemone mexicana (oil) Sanguinarine Epidemic dropsy
Millet Crotalaria seeds (Jhunjhunia) Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites 
Bajra, wheat Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Ergotism

 * BOAA-Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine
